descript.abstract: The PAMP (Principal Areas of Mine Pollution) data set is a compilation of 2,422 mining operations and their potential water quality problems. This information was originally compiled in 1972 by the Division of Mines and Geology for the State Water Resources Control Board. It was published in a series of volumes of tabular data. The data set includes operations where production exceeded $100,000 or where other factors indicated a high potential for water quality impacts.
descript.purpose: The PAMP data set was converted to a digital format by the Office of Mine Reclamation to provide a digital data set describing abandoned mines that may have pollution problems. This data set is not intended to be a statement of fact that any of the listed sites do have such problems. Instead, it provides a starting point for locating and investigating abandoned mines in order to make such a determination. It is a known fact that the coordinates of the mines in this data set often have poor spatial accuracy. Because of this, additional information sources should be consulted to accurately locate the sites.

idinfo.datacred: Sarah Reeves, Eric Miller, Hiep Trinh, Gail Newton, Mike Tuffly

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.0 (Build 2195) Service Pack 4; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.0.0.535

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

distinfo.distliab: The Department of Conservation makes no warranties as to the suitability of this product for any particular purpose.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Concatenation of the printed volume number and the tabular record identification number.

procstep.procdesc: Tabular data from paper reports was entered into a spreadsheet, which was imported into ArcView and converted into a shapefile.

citeinfo.origin: California Division of Mines and Geology
citeinfo.title: Principal Areas of Mine Pollution

pubinfo.publish: California Division of Mines and Geology

citeinfo.othercit: This dataset was prepared as part of the Basin Planning Study done by the California Water Resources Control Board.

dataqual.complete: The original data set was compiled based on mines that had greater than $100,000 of production or that had other factors indicating a potential pollution problem. There is no information about whether any attempt was made to normalize the dollar figures used in the selection criteria or what the additional selection criteria were. It is not possible to determine the completeness of the data, and it is likely there were many ommissions of mines that may have pollution problems but did not meet the selection criteria. Seventeen columns from the original tables were not included in this dataset. These columns were almost entirely devoid of data.

horizpa.horizpar: Coordinates in the original data set were given in degrees and decimal minutes with up to two decimal places. Anecdotal spatial accuracy assessments indicate the data is generally of poor spatial accuracy and is often off by as much as 1,000 meters. It is likely that the original data set was compiled using reported USPLSS coordinates, and therefore may represent the center of a section or the center of a quarter section. However, because the USPLSS has been adjusted over the years, transcription of very old information to coordinates using more recent maps likely introduced another source of error. Additionally, typing errors have been discovered and corrected for a few coordinates where the error was obvious, such as transposition resulting in 112 for a longitude coordinate that should have been 121. Non-obvious errors were entered as reported in the original document. The locations in this dataset should be verified if precise mine locations are required.

attracc.attraccr: The attributes of the data set have been transcribed from the original printed format. Coordinates were given in decimal minutes, so an additional field containing a conversion to decimal degrees was created. Due to field length limitations imposed by the database, some data in some fields is truncated. One will encounter these truncated fields from time to time where a word abruptly ends. There is no intention to revisit and remedy the data affected by this.

dataqual.logic: The original data source was comprised of tabular data with fairly free form text entries under each of these fields. No effort was made to "normalize" this information, and it was input verbatim.
